questions.text: A 30-year-old woman at 41 weeks and 5 days of gestation reports a decrease in fetal movements over the past few days. Which of the following complications is not associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Maternal

Perinatal

Fetal macrosomia:

 

Is a common complication of post-dated pregnancies due to the extended period of fetal growth.

Stillbirth

Oligohydramnios:

 

Reduced amniotic fluid, because the placenta becomes less efficient at maintaining amniotic fluid levels as it ages.

Post-maturity syndrome

Pre-eclampsia

Meconium aspiration syndrome:

 

The fetus is more likely to pass meconium into the amniotic fluid, which can be inhaled into the lungs during birth.

Postpartum hemorrhagic

Hypoxic ischemia encephalopathy

Labour dystocia

Birth injuries

Perineal lacerations

Childhood obesity

questions.text: Which of the following cannot access premature rupture of the membranes?
questions.explanation:
Diagnostic Method

Description

Speculum Examination

Aseptic inspection to observe fluid escaping through the cervix

Nitrazine Paper Test

pH indicator paper; turns blue (pH >6) indicating amniotic fluid (AF)

Fern Test (Ferning Pattern)

Microscopic examination of vaginal fluid smear for characteristic fern-like pattern

Nile Blue Sulfate Stain

Stains exfoliated cells from fetal sebaceous glands; orange-blue colour indicates AF

AmniSure Rapid Immunoassay

Rapid test to detect specific proteins in vaginal fluid indicative of AF

Ultrasonography

Used to visualise amniotic fluid levels around the fetus; supports diagnosis and assesses fetal well-being.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman at 41 weeks and 5 days of gestation presents to the labor with complaints of decreased fetal movements. The urine protein on dipstick is negative. USG reveals a small for gestational age fetus in cephalic presentation, with AFI-5 cm, placenta is fundal. All of the following are done in managing this patient except:

A 28-year-old woman presents to her obstetrician at 41 weeks and 3 days of gestation. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated, with normal fetal growth and no signs of preeclampsia or gestational diabetes. She reports feeling well; fetal movements are still noticeable but slightly reduced. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The ultrasound reveals normal amniotic fluid levels. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this uncomplicated post-dated pregnancy?

A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 42 weeks of gestation with labour pain. An ultrasound reveals oligohydramnios and a large-for-gestational-age fetus. The newborn is delivered with dry, peeling skin weighing 4kg. What is the most likely diagnosis for this newborn?
Which of the following is not seen in post-dated pregnancy?
A primigravida 42 weeks of gestation comes to the ER with labour pain. She is at increased risk of all of the following complications except :
questions.explanation:
During labour

After birth
  • Fetal hypoxia / Acidosis
  • Meconium Aspiration
  • Cord compression (Option C)
  • Shoulder dystocia.
  • Increased incidence of operative delivery
  • Chemical pneumonitis due to meconium aspiration
  • Нурохia
  • Hypoglycemia/polycythemia
  • Nicu admissions are increased

questions.text: A 31-year-old pregnant woman at 34 weeks of gestation presents to the ER with a fever of 100.8°F and complains of lower abdominal pain. On examination, her membranes are ruptured, and she is in active labour. The attending physician suspects chorioamnionitis. The best-suited management for this patient is?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer antibiotics and observe for improvement before considering delivery.

options.label: B
options.text: Induce labour with oxytocin and administer antibiotics simultaneously.

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate cesarean section without administering antibiotics.

options.label: D
options.text: Administer antibiotics and prepare for immediate delivery, either vaginal or cesarean.

questions.correct_answer: D. Administer antibiotics and prepare for immediate delivery, either vaginal or cesarean.

questions.text: A pregnant female at 14 weeks of gestation comes to the OPD for routine examination. On a pervaginal examination, there is a 2 cm dilation of the cervix. She also has a previous similar history of mid-trimester spontaneous abortion. You planned to do cervical cerclage. All are contraindications except

A patient presents with slow leak of watery vaginal discharge at 36 weeks of gestation. There is no history of trauma. The PH of the fluid turns out to be 7 and turns the Nitrazine paper from yellow to blue. What is the likely aetiology of the above scenario except?
questions.explanation:
• Previous history of PTL (preterm labour )
  • Pregnancy followed by ART(Assisted reproductive technique)
  • Asymptomatic bacteriuria / recent UTI
  • Smoking
  • Low Socioeconomic Status
  • Maternal Stress
  • regnancy-related complication
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • APH ( Antepartum hemorrhagic)
  • Polyhydramnios
  • Uterine Anomalies
  • Chronic diseases like HTN and DM
  • Multiple pregnancies
  • Iatrogenic
  • Idiopathic

questions.text: All of the following are contraindications of tocolysis except:
What is the definition of early preterm labour according to ACOG guidelines?

options.label: A
options.text: Labour that occurs before 24 weeks of gestation.

options.label: B
options.text: Labour that occurs before 34 weeks of gestation.

options.label: C
options.text: Labour that occurs between 32 and <37 weeks of gestation.

options.label: D
options.text: Labour that occurs between 34 and 36 weeks of gestation.

questions.correct_answer: B. Labour that occurs before 34 weeks of gestation.
questions.explanation:
Term

Definition according to (ACOG)

Preterm

Birth before 37 weeks of gestation
  • Early Preterm

Birth before 34 weeks of gestation
  • Late Preterm (Option D)

Birth between 34 and 36+6 weeks of gestation

Full Term

Birth between 39 and 40+6 weeks of gestation

Early Term

Birth between 37 and 38+6 weeks of gestation

Postterm

Birth at 42 weeks of gestation or later

Term

Definition according to WHO

Extremely Preterm (Option A)

Birth before 28 completed weeks of gestation

Very Preterm

Birth from 28 to less than 32 completed weeks

Moderate to Late Preterm (Option C)

Birth from 32 to less than 37 completed weeks

Full Term

Birth from 37 to less than 42 completed weeks

Postterm

Birth at 42 completed weeks of gestation or later

questions.text: To confirm lung maturity, how much fetal RBCs should be orange?
Which of the following tests is not used for assessing fetal pulmonary maturity?
questions.explanation:
Assessment Method

Description

Lecithin/Sphingomyelin (L/S) Ratio (estimation of pulmonary surfactant)

L/S ratio of 1 at 31-32 weeks, 2 at 35 weeks, and >2.2 indicates pulmonary maturity

Shake/Clement's/bubble Test

Amniotic fluid is mixed with ethanol; stable foam formation indicates pulmonary maturity

Foam Stability Index (FSI)

Quantitative measure of surfactant presence using serial dilutions; FSI of 47 virtually excludes RDS

Presence of Phosphatidylglycerol (PG)

Detectable by thin-layer chromatography; presence indicates lung maturation

Saturated phosphatidylcholine

500 ng/mL or more indicates maturity

Fluorescence Polarization

Measures surfactant to albumin ratio; presence of 55 mg/g surfactant indicates lung maturity

Amniotic Fluid Optical Density at 650 nm

Optical density >0.15 indicates lung maturity

Lamellar Body Count

Count >30,000/µl indicates pulmonary maturity

Orange Colored Cells (Nile Blue Sulfate Stain)

Presence of >50% orange-colored cells suggests pulmonary maturity

Amniotic Fluid Turbidity

Becomes turbid at term due to vernix; not directly used as a primary marker for maturity

questions.text: A 32-year-old female, G3 P2 L2 with h/o two spontaneous early preterm births is seen in routine antenatal OPD. Which of the following can prevent her risk of spontaneous preterm birth?

A 32-year-old female G2 P1 presented with a history of preterm delivery in the previous pregnancy, resulting in the child presenting with cerebral palsy. Which of the following has a neuroprotective role for the fetus in cases of extreme prematurity?

A 28-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks gestation presents with regular uterine contractions every 5 minutes associated with mild lower abdominal discomfort. On examination, her cervix is 2 cm dilated and 50% effaced. Fetal heart rate monitoring shows no signs of distress. Which of the following is the tocolytic of choice?
questions.explanation:
Objective
  • To delay delivery at least 48 hours for glucocorticoid therapy (for fetal lung maturation)

C/I
  • Maternal
    • Uncontrolled diabetes, thyrotoxicosis, severe hypertension, cardiac disease, haemorrhage in pregnancy.
  • Fetal
    • Fetal distress, fetal death, congenital malformation, pregnancy beyond 34 weeks
  • Others
    • Rupture of membranes, chorioamnionitis, cervical dilation of more than 4 cm

Drugs
  • Calcium channel blockers
    • Nifedipine, Nicardipine, Verapamil
  • Magnesium sulfate
  • Indomethacin
  • Sulindac
  • Betamimetics
    • Terbutaline, Ritodrine, Isoxsuprine
  • Atosiban
  • Glyceryl trinitrate

questions.text: A pregnant female at 32 weeks gestation presents with signs of preterm labour. To promote fetal lung maturity, which medications and doses should be administered?

options.label: A
options.text: Betamethasone 12 mg IM, repeated after 24 hours

options.label: B
options.text: Dexamethasone 6 mg IM, repeated after 24 hours

options.label: D
options.text: Prednisolone 20 mg PO daily for 7 days

questions.correct_answer: A. Betamethasone 12 mg IM, repeated after 24 hours
questions.explanation:
Corticosteroid

Dosage and Administration

Mechanism of Action

Betamethasone (Preferred choice)

12 mg IM, repeated after 24 hours (2 doses)

Enhances fetal lung maturation by stimulating surfactant production

Dexamethasone (Alternative)

6 mg IM, repeated every 12 hours (4 doses)

Similar mechanism to betamethasone

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, G2P1, at 32 weeks gestation, presents to the emergency department with complaints of regular uterine contractions every 10 minutes and lower back pain. She denies any leakage of fluid or vaginal bleeding. Upon examination, her cervix is found to be 3 cm dilated and 80% effaced. Fetal heart rate monitoring shows a reactive pattern. Which of the following complications is not anticipated in this patient with preterm labour?
questions.explanation:
Fetal Complications

Maternal Complications
  • Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS)
  • Bronchopulmonary Dysplasia (BPD)
  • Intraventricular Hemorrhage (IVH)
  • Necrotizing Enterocolitis (NEC)
  • Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP)
  • Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA)
  • Pneumonia/sepsis
  • Periventricular leukomalacia (PVL)
  • Cerebral palsy (CP)
  • Neurodevelopmental Impairment
  • Postpartum Hemorrhage
  • Infection
  • Psychological Impact
  • Increased Cesarean Delivery Rates
  • Complications from Prolonged Bed Rest

questions.text: A 28-year-old primi at 30 weeks gestation presents with complaints of lower abdominal pain and backache. She has no significant medical history. On examination, her cervix is closed, but there are mild irregular uterine contractions. The obstetrician plans to measure fetal fibronectin (fFN) to assess the risk of preterm labour. Which of the following statements about fetal fibronectin (fFN) is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a glycoprotein at the interface of the chorion and the decidua.

options.label: B
options.text: Functions as adhesive glue between the fetal membranes and decidua.

options.label: C
options.text: Testing is typically performed between 24 and 34 weeks of gestation.

options.label: D
options.text: A negative test is highly predictive of delivery within the next 7 days.

questions.correct_answer: D. A negative test is highly predictive of delivery within the next 7 days.
questions.explanation:
Origin

Fetal fibronectin (fFN) is a glycoprotein produced by fetal cells.

Found at the interface of the chorion and the decidua

Mechanism
  • Function in intercellular adhesion during implantation.
  • Normally present in cervical and vaginal secretions in early pregnancy and again in late pregnancy, typically not found between 22 and 34 weeks.
  • Disruption of this "glue" (due to inflammation, infection, or physical disruption) releases fFN into the cervicovaginal secretions.

Uses

Measurement of fFN levels in cervicovaginal secretions can help predict the risk of preterm birth. Recommended for symptomatic women between 24 and 34 weeks of gestation.

  • Positive Result: Indicates a higher risk of preterm birth, but it is not definitive.
  • Negative Result: Suggests a low risk of preterm birth within the next 7-14 days.

Limitations
  • Positive results do not guarantee preterm labour
  • Recent sexual activity, vaginal examination, or the presence of lubricants or disinfectants can affect test accuracy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for preterm labour?
